Title: AMC Networks Sheds 5% Of Global Workforce Via Voluntary Buyouts
URL: http://deadline.com/2025/11/amc-networks-workforce-voluntary-buyouts-1236610587/
Time Published: 2025-11-07T14:28:30Z
Full Content:
By Dade Hayes Business Editor AMC Networks, which is continuing to navigate the transition from linear TV to streaming, is shedding less than 5% of its global workforce of 1,800 employees via voluntary buyouts. CEO Kristin Dolan announced the reduction Friday during the companyâ€™s third-quarter earnings call with Wall Street analysts. The company had earlier reported mixed results for the quarter, with advertising sliding 17% but streaming revenue climbing 14%. In the companyâ€™s earnings release, Dolan called the quarterly performance â€œa key milestone in our transition from a cable networks business to a global streaming and technology focused content company.â€ Dolan said â€œless than 5%â€ of the workforce would be departing as a result of an initiative to â€œensure we have the right skills for the future.â€ She added that company leaders are â€œthankful for the contributions of those who have chosen to pursue new opportunities, and of course those who are driving this new era of the company.â€ Watch on Deadline AMC Networks, parent of cable networks AMC, IFC, Sundance TV, We TV and BBC America, also operates a portfolio of niche streaming services AMC+, Shudder and Acorn TV, with a total of 10.4 million subscribers. The downsizing at AMC Networks comes during a much broader pullback across the entertainment sector. Paramount, in the wake of its merger with Skydance, is laying off about 2,000 workers, about 10% of its total head count. Warner Bros. Discovery recently initiated layoffs in its cable business, and is likely to be part of more cutbacks as it nears a transaction to either be acquired or split into two companies. Disney also let several hundred workers go last summer. It isnâ€™t just traditional media tightening the belt, however. Advances in artificial intelligence are resulting in significant cuts even at Big Tech firms. Amazon last month said it was cutting 14,000 corporate employees, including in publishing and video game development. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Shut down linear, license legacy content to Netflix and YouTube, and deploy capital to produce new low-quantity, high-quality projects. There needs to be some infrastructure to invest in projects in the first place. Title: â€˜Do I need it?â€™ Groceries cost 20% to 40% more than before the pandemic. How San Diegans are making do
URL: https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/2025/11/07/do-i-need-it-groceries-cost-20-to-40-more-than-before-the-pandemic-how-san-diegans-are-making-do/
Time Published: 2025-11-07T14:17:49Z
Full Content:
Mike Portal uses a no-fee credit card that gives 6% back on groceries. He pays it off every month. The chicken drumsticks in Chris Lovelaceâ€™s freezer cost 99 cents a pound, far cheaper than the red meat he used to buy. Margi Thornburgh, a night owl, checks ads and clips coupons every Wednesday at midnight and hunts for more discounts on store shelves. â€œI really get a thrill out of getting a bargain,â€ she said after spotting $1.99 smoothies at Vons recently, down from $3.99. Because they were half off, she bought 12 instead of six. â€œI was skipping out of the store with a big smile on my face.â€ These are some of San Diegoâ€™s super shoppers, who have been training for this era of fast rising grocery prices for decades. Some have the resources to turn frugal shopping into a sport of sorts â€” a car that lets them buy in bulk, time to shop for deals, storage space, multiple grocery stores close to home. For others, strapped for space or time, the path to eating adequately while not overspending is more challenging. Grocery prices have risen for a mix of reasons, including pandemic-era supply chain blockages and import tariffs that are passed on to shoppers. In San Diego County, food eaten outside of restaurants cost 4.4% more this July than a year earlier. That is the latest figure from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, whose publications stopped due to the federal shutdown. Fresher data â€” St. Louis Federal Reserve Bankâ€™s nationwide FRED figures for September â€” show milk prices were up 10 cents a gallon over last year and up 68 cents over five years earlier, a rise of almost 20%. White bread was down 11 cents from last year but up 38 cents from five years earlier, about 25% higher. Ground beef cost $6.32 a pound, up from $5.67 a year ago and $4.08 in 2020. In the San Diego metro area, meat was 41% higher last month than in October 2019, dairy was 27% higher and produce was 18% higher, according to a grocery price index by Datasembly, a market analytics company that tracks prices of 1,000 products weekly across the United States. Local prices of meat and non-alcoholic beverages kept rising in the past six months, produce is almost even, and dairy and bakery items have fallen slightly, Datasembly found. Faced with these higher prices, San Diegans have changed how they plan and eat. They are abandoning foods and replacing stores they shopped at for decades with ones that have sales and coupons. Theyâ€™re clinging to a few favorite items â€” Diet Coke, Diet Snapple, eggs and bourbon were mentioned. But theyâ€™re giving up a degree of control, opting to eat whatâ€™s on sale and not what theyâ€™re craving. Theyâ€™re doing the math: if I spend this much on gas to drive around or spring for a freezer, but I save that much on food, is it worth it? As a teenager, Thornburgh learned to write grocery lists and shop weekly sales. Some 50 years later, she still uses those methods. But as local food prices have risen, outpacing the national inflation rate, Thornburgh has taken things further, combining every strategy she can think of so she doesnâ€™t spend more than she must. â€œI look at all the ads either through the emails I receive or directly on the apps. I make my list by store of which items that I want to purchase. â€¦ Iâ€™m able to shop at multiple stores in one trip. I always bring a cooler to store cold and frozen items,â€ she outlined in an email to The San Diego Union-Tribune. Strolling through aisles, she keeps looking for deals. â€œI can be in a store, see an item on the shelf, and I will pull up the Target app, the Walmart app, the Food 4 Less app,â€ she said. â€œAny app of the store that Iâ€™m not in. And I will look for the price â€¦ and I will say, â€˜Am I going to buy this here or am I going to go to another store?â€™â€ Her weekly grocery loop is time intensive, taking 90 minutes to two hours and covering as much as seven miles. Stops include Walmart, Food 4 less, Trader Joeâ€™s and Vons. She recently folded in Aldi, drawn by an ad for 55-cent avocados. She picked those up, plus raspberries and asparagus, all on sale. Thornburgh, 70, gets income from contract sewing and Social Security. She is not among the 53% of adults who, according to a poll by AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research, see grocery expenses as a â€œmajor source of stress.â€ (Groceries beat housing and health care costs and having inadequate savings or income as the top financial worry.) â€œI feel that Iâ€™m skilled enough and take advantage of all the tools out there,â€ she said. â€œI donâ€™t feel stressed. But Iâ€™m very conscientious.â€ She reminds her husband: â€œIf itâ€™s not on sale, Iâ€™m not buying it. So he was really happy this week when Ding Dongs were on sale.â€ With these efforts, she spends around $100 a week, up from $60 before the pandemic, and saves around 50% on average at Vons and 40% at Food 4 Less. â€œWith the money I save, itâ€™s worth the investment of time,â€ she said. Thornburgh offered one more hint: donâ€™t just shop online. Go inside stores. She acknowledged that shopping online and picking up groceries is convenient for some people, including parents of young children, but â€œyou will miss the in-store sales, and sometimes those are substantial.â€ Jeff Lonsdale, Ken Sobel and Chris Lovelace are cutting back on red meat. â€œI donâ€™t buy steaks anymore,â€ said Lonsdale, 68, who lives in a mobile retirement community in Oceanside. A half-package of sirloin burgers from Costco has been sitting in his freezer because he has â€œbetter, more affordable choicesâ€ today. He used to buy what he wanted, but as his income as a contract circuit designer fell and food prices hit new highs â€” especially for the beef burgers, steaks and pork chops he once enjoyed â€” he has changed his habits. â€œIt used to be: I want it, Iâ€™ll go get it. Now I think, do I need it? Then maybe I go get it,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t need doughnuts and cakes and desserts and that kind of thing, so I donâ€™t even bother.â€ Currently, he said, â€œmy income is short of expenses each month. My savings account keeps me above water.â€ Worried about cash flow, Lonsdale started tracking all food spending this year â€” both at stores and the occasional trip to Taco Bell. All together, his monthly spending on food is around $65 this year, he said. A food rescue program he visits three times a week helps him hold down costs, bringing surplus items from local grocery stores to his community. Around 40 people visit each time, he estimated. One recent morning, he picked up seafood salad with crackers, a 12-ounce watermelon cup, two mesquite-seasoned pork chops that totaled 12 ounces, an Earthbound Farms brand veggie tray with ranch dip, baby carrots, broccoli and celery, a Nathanâ€™s hot dog and a 6-ounce Caesar salad. Based on the price tags he saw, he said the total might be around $20. â€œI mean, would you spend $3.99 for a little tray of cut up watermelon?â€ he said. â€œI get it for free and Iâ€™m loving it. And itâ€™s not just the volume. Itâ€™s the variety. Things I have never thought about trying, never knew they had, wouldnâ€™t have looked for.â€ Another nice surprise: goat cheese with herbs. â€œWow, Iâ€™ll try that. Itâ€™s free. It was good.â€ Sobel, 71, who lives in La Jolla, cut out most meat and some other high-cost grocery items. â€œSticker shock was a huge part of it â€” the prices that went higher all the time and the quality going down, almost commensurately,â€ he said. â€œThat brought my focus back into buying only healthy foods, buying only what Iâ€™m going to eat, being careful about our choices.â€ After a hospitalization, Sobel decided to lose weight. He changed his diet in June and stopped buying â€œa lot of the high-price, mass-produced snack foods â€¦ that have skyrocketed in price.â€ One more change: â€œI really donâ€™t throw away food anymore.â€ He makes a chef salad using turkey breast or sliced ham and eats that several days in a row, â€œuntil itâ€™s completely gone.â€ â€œIâ€™m lucky enough to be able to cut about 40% from my food budget and afford to eat,â€ added Sobel, who reduced his householdâ€™s average monthly grocery bill from around $550 (not counting the occasional restaurant delivery) before June to around $400 now. â€œBut what about kids and seniors and low-income families who are losing their SNAP benefits?â€ Almost 400,000 San Diego County residents saw their CalFresh benefits â€” the stateâ€™s version of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) â€” halted Nov. 1 amid a federal government shutdown, now in its sixth week. Federal judges later ordered that funds be restarted. Between workers whose pay was frozen by the federal shutdown and people whose food benefits were postponed or trimmed, demand is surging at food banks and food-rescue nonprofits, whether in small communities like Lonsdaleâ€™s or at large distribution centers. In Encinitas, Lovelace rarely buys red meat at the store anymore. Instead, he goes out for quality burgers. â€œItâ€™s got really, really good meat,â€ he said of Versailles Cafeâ€™s $18 cheeseburger and fries. â€œItâ€™s a real half pound, not a seven ouncer.â€ Lovelaceâ€™s rooftop solar on the house he and his wife, Dana, bought almost 50 years ago powers the two chest freezers he keeps in his garage. â€œI still donâ€™t have any chicken breast in my freezer that I paid over $2 a pound for,â€ he said. Bacon was purchased at $4 a pound â€” around half of what it costs now full price. He is still working through the dozen packages of breakfast sausage he bought at half-off a while back. When he shops, he buys enough meat to last until the next big sale. Lovelace, who is 75 and retired, stopped shopping at stores that donâ€™t send weekly ads. Like Thornburgh, he lives in a grocery-dense neighborhood with â€œall the big chains, so itâ€™s really easy to get to places.â€ He focuses on house brands over pricier, name-brand versions. In-season food is also cheaper, he added. And he knows the market. â€œYou have to know your prices. Sometimes that good deal really isnâ€™t,â€ he said. These efforts are keeping the coupleâ€™s grocery costs almost even with last year: $560 a month in 2023 and 2024 and $577 this year, on average. â€œDoubtless expenses will begin to rise this holiday season as we liquidate our older inventories but weâ€™ll still be kicking butt on money spent for food compared to any of my friends or neighbors when we compare notes on this topic,â€ Lovelace wrote in an email. He also credited his wife, who embraces his â€œcheapo philosophy.â€ In Mt. Helix, Portal is back to shopping like he did when he was a newlywed in the early 1990s â€” only now he has that cash-back credit card. â€œI was in the beginning of my career,â€ he said of his frugal youth. â€œWe chose to have my wife stay home and take care of the babies. So, yeah, we pinched pennies and cut corners to save money.â€ Now his kids have kids and Portal, 65, has a home on Mt. Helix and a mortgage consulting business. But with the â€œtremendous increase in food costsâ€ he has observed this year, he buys food on sale and stopped shopping at Whole Foods. â€œItâ€™s just too high.â€ His small freezer holds berries bought on sale, which his toddler grandchildren devour. He also buys discounted meat and uses a vacuum sealer to avoid freezer burn. Ribeye on sale rose from $6 a pound to $9 or more, but even that is a relative bargain compared to full price, he said. Uncooked beef steaks cost on average $10.88 a pound last September and $12.26 this September, up from $8.13 five years ago, according to St. Louis Fed FRED data. To keep grocery expenses roughly the same as last year, even while springing for steak â€” and the chicken he cooks for RiRi, his 13-year-old Labrador pitbull mix â€” Portal and his wife stock up ahead of big holidays, when sales are â€œthe best.â€ He gushed about his credit card, an American Express Blue Cash Everyday Card. Never carrying a balance is key, he said. Portal pointed value hunters to GTM Discount General Store, a surplus seller whose weekly sale recently featured 50% off Eddie Bauer sweatshirts, 40% off flood lightbulbs and 40% off spring wreaths. It has great deals on food, Portal added. Lovelace said heâ€™s lucky to have two freezers and the garage shelves he built himself. â€œWe have places to put stuff, and some people donâ€™t. A lot of the things we do donâ€™t apply across the board.â€ But his approach of stocking up when prices drop has worked across his lifetime. â€œIn any given era, the same rule applies: prices on food have not gone down realistically over any real period of time in my lifetime. Little dips down and big jumps up,â€ he said.

Title: October Layoffs Were the Worst Since 2003 and Hit Tech Workers Hard
URL: https://gizmodo.com/october-layoffs-were-the-worst-since-2003-and-hit-tech-workers-hard-2000682936
Time Published: 2025-11-07T14:15:59Z
Full Content:
Reading time 2 minutes A lot of people can feel that the economy isnâ€™t doing so hot right now. Unfortunately, due to the government shutdown, we donâ€™t have much in the way of official economic data to give statistical clarity to that feeling. However, more and more, private firms are releasing their economic analysis, and, much of the time, it doesnâ€™t bode well for the American worker. Now, a new report shows that this October was a particularly brutal month for the U.S. workforceÃ¢Â€Â”and it was especially bad for the tech industry. The analysis, from career transition services firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas, shows that this past month was the worst in decades. The report states that U.S. employers announced some â€œ153,074 job cuts in October, up 175% from the 55,597 cuts announced in October 2024. It is up 183% from the 54,064 job cuts announced one month prior.â€ Yikes, thatâ€™s a lot. And the cuts have been especially deep for Silicon Valley: Technology continues to lead in private-sector job cuts as companies restructure amid AI integration, slower demand, and efficiency pressures. In October, the sector announced 33,281 job cuts, up sharply from 5,639 in September. For the year, Technology firms have announced 141,159 job cuts, up 17% from the 120,470 announced through the same period in 2024. Yeah, thatâ€™s bad. That is not good at all. Thereâ€™s no real way to spin that as good. Ã¢Â€ÂœThis is the highest total for October in over 20 years, and the highest total for a single month in the fourth quarter since 2008,â€ the report states. â€œLike in 2003, a disruptive technology is changing the landscape.â€ Ã¢Â€ÂœOctoberÃ¢Â€Â™s pace of job cutting was much higher than average for the month. Some industries are correcting after the hiring boom of the pandemic, but this comes as AI adoption, softening consumer and corporate spending, and rising costs drive belt-tightening and hiring freezes,â€ said Andy Challenger, workplace expert and chief revenue officer for Challenger, Gray & Christmas. â€œThose laid off now are finding it harder to quickly secure new roles, which could further loosen the labor market.Ã¢Â€Â Weâ€™ve already written about the huge layoffs that impacted the tech industry last monthÃ¢Â€Â”including some 14,000 people who used to be (but are no longer) employed with Amazon. The exact reason for why tech companies are shedding jobs right now is still up in the air. One narrative attributes the layoffs to the rise of AI, but other commentators have noted that it could be much more mundane economic/business factors that are squeezing the industry like a lack of growth in non-AI sectors and tariff policy eating away at profits while making it difficult to plan for the future. Title: Economists agree: Youâ€™re not crazy for feeling like the rich get richer, and the poor are doing worse. Welcome to the â€˜K-shaped economyâ€™
URL: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/economists-agree-not-crazy-feeling-140000181.html
Time Published: 2025-11-07T14:00:00Z
Description: What was a niche argument about five years ago is suddenly everywhere you look, and itâ€™s taking on the shape of a letter with two jagged edges.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Economists agree: Youâ€™re not crazy for feeling like the rich get richer, and the poor are doing worse. Welcome to the â€˜K-shaped economyâ€™
URL: https://fortune.com/2025/11/07/what-is-the-k-shaped-economy-wealth-inequality-explainer/
Time Published: 2025-11-07T14:00:00Z
Full Content:
Sasha Rogelberg is a reporter and former editorial fellow on the news desk at Fortune, covering retail and the intersection of business and popular culture. Eva is a fellow on Fortune's news desk. It all began with an anonymous Twitter handle named â€œIvan the K.â€ The self-appointed â€œLead Independent Director of Finance Twitterâ€ had a dark theory in the depths of the pandemic. In 2020, they asked the universe, â€œWhy is no one talking about a K recovery?â€ since there was much discussion at that time about an economic bounceback in the shape of either a U, an L, or, most bullish of all, a V. â€œSome things will bounce back,â€ Ivan wrote, â€œsome will not recover. Think about it.â€ Economists seem to have thunk on it and agreed: The K is real. It bears similarities to another saying, invented nearly 200 years earlier by the great English romantic poet Percy Bysshe Shelley: â€œThe rich get richer, the poor get poorer.â€ This is also called â€œthe Matthew effect,â€ as some trace the sentiment all the way back to the bibleâ€™s Book of Matthew 25:29: â€œFor to everyone who has, more will be given, and he will have abundance; but from the one who does not have, even what he has will be taken away.â€ If you ask Mark Zandi, chief economist for Moodyâ€™s Analytics, this old-time religion got a new lease on life in the Reaganomics of the 1980s. â€œYou really start to see this in the Reagan era,â€ Zandi told Fortune. â€œThatâ€™s when you get a structural divergence between productivity growth and median wage growth.â€ Zandi argued that many elements combined then to weaken labor in favor of capital income: globalization, the decline of unions and manufacturing and major tax reforms. â€œThe share of national income going to labor has been trending down since the early 1980s,â€ he said, â€œand the share going to capital ownersâ€”those who already have wealthâ€”has gone up.â€ So what is it about 2025, five years after the pandemic severed something economically, that accelerated both sides of the â€œKâ€ for the wealthy and the poor? First, consider the extraordinary surges in economic data seen, halfway through the 2020s. The stock market rallies have led to several record highs in 2025, incentivizing the (wealthier) Americans with money in the markets to loosen their purse strings. But the bottom half of the K is extending downwards, with fast-casual restaurants like Chipotle and Cava, and fast-food joints like McDonaldâ€™s, noting that lower-income customers, especially young people, are pulling back and preferring to dine at home. Zandiâ€™s own research has turned up some stunning results, notably that in the second quarter of 2025 the top 10% of wealthiest Americans were responsible for a whopping 49% of consumer spending. That means the economy has grown so lopsidedâ€”or K-shapedâ€”that the richest Americans are responsible for half the economy. The K-shape is creating the illusion in economic data that despite sticky inflation and tariff-related sticker shock, consumer spending remains â€œresilient.â€ Morgan Stanley Wealth Managementâ€™s Lisa Shalett has increasingly been sounding the alarm from her perch as chief investment officer. She told Fortune in an October interview that â€œthe income inequality stuff is really getting like completely wackadoo,â€ specifically citing Zandiâ€™s research: â€œThat means 90% of the country is only half the consumption, I mean holy cannoli.â€ Shalett covered the K-shaped economy specifically in a November 3 research note, in the context of whether 2026 marks an early or late stage of the economic cycle for investors. â€œDecoding this conundrum may hinge on the so-called K-shaped economy,â€ she wrote, â€œa concept that captures the widening chasm between the â€˜havesâ€™ and â€˜have-nots.â€™â€ Then Shalett said the situation is actually even worse than what Zandi produced: â€œFor the U.S. consumer, wealth concentration has produced a situation where the top 40% of households by income account for approximately 60% of all spending; those households, in turn, control nearly 85% of Americaâ€™s wealth, two-thirds of which is directly tied to the stock market, which has climbed more than 90% in three years.â€ She calculated that spending by the wealthiest households was growing 6x-7x faster than for the lowest cohort. Even Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell talked about seeing the pattern at Octoberâ€™s Federal Open Market Committee meeting. â€œIf you listen to the earnings calls or the reports of big, public, consumer-facing companies, many of them are saying that thereâ€™s a bifurcated economy there and that consumers at the lower end are struggling and buying less and shifting to lower cost products,â€ Powell said last week. â€œBut at the top, people are spending, at the higher income and wealth.â€ The concept of a bifurcated economy has been baked into American society longer than even the days of Reagan, according to Tyler Schipper, associate professor of economics at the University of St. Thomas. â€œThereâ€™s this underlying thing that has been true for decades and decades and decades,â€ Schipper told Fortune. â€œNumber one, lower income households always struggle more in the economy. They tend to be more impacted by price changes because theyâ€™re spending a higher percentage of their income. â€œAnd second, that it tends to be that after each recession, lower income workers fall further behind in the income distribution,â€ he added. Today, conversations around the shape of the American economy are more urgent because more of the middle classâ€”and those making about $100,000 per yearâ€”are getting pushed into the lower half of the K, Schipper said. This can be seen in mid-income and higher-income earners flocking to discount retailers like Walmart and Dollar General. It can even take on more absurd forms, with â€œRalph Lauren Christmasâ€ trending at unprecedented levels heading into the projected $1 trillion 2025 holiday season, but TikTok and Instagram full of tips on how to achieve the look of red-tartan-plaid and cozy sweaters on a budgetâ€”in other words, not at an actually expensive Ralph Lauren store. That lower half of the K is extending ever downward as the consumer encounters a unique set of challenges, including the inflationary impact of tariffs, according to Schipper. Lower-income households tend to spend more on essential goods more likely to be impacted by tariffs. The Yale Budget Lab calculated that the levies impact the bottom of the income ladder more than three times more than the top. A low-fire, low-hire labor market has also contributed to evidence of a two-tiered economy, said Claudia Sahm, chief economist at New Century Advisors and a former Federal Reserve economist. While tech layoffs have been top of mind following massive cuts from Amazon, layoff rates are still low, Sahm told Fortune, meaning if you have a job, you may feel more financially secure. If youâ€™re just entering the job market like Gen Z is, you may have a hard time finding a job as firms contract following a post-COVID hiring spree, and as AI begins to displace entry-level jobs. To be sure, data from Challenger, Gray & Christmas released on Thursday found U.S. employers cut more than 150,000 jobs last month, the largest October reduction in two decades. But another part of the resurgence of discussions about a bifurcated economy comes from the relative nature of a K-shaped economy, according to Schipper. While the economy has historically been two-tiered, diverging consumer sentiment has also contributed to a narrative that two income groups are moving away from each other. For example, in 2022 when the stock market declined, consumer sentiment in both the top-third and bottom-third of income levels converged, according to data from the University of Michiganâ€™s Survey of Consumers. A similar pattern occurred in April, when the announcement of Liberation Day tariffs spooked Americans across income levels, Schipper noted. Last month, however, consumer attitude toward the economy saw a greater split, with low-income Americans feeling far less confident about the economy than those high-income. Some economists point to the widening divide between the rich and the poor as a consequence of monetary policy. The Fed, over the past few years, has had a historic tightening cycle â€“ eleven rate hikes between 2022 and 2024â€”which was meant to pare down inflation. However, it also reinforced the split since wealthy households, flush by years of asset appreciation, could weather the slowdown better than lower income households facing higher mortgage rates and shrinking credit, Zandi said. Cheap money in the 2010s and early pandemic years boosted stocks and home values, but the 2022-and-on tightening squeezed borrowers and renters without necessarily reversing those gains. That means even as inflation has cooled, the damage lingered as asset holders retained their windfall but wage earners bore the brunt of disinflation. â€œFolks in the top third of the income and wealth distribution are doing well, but the remaining two-thirds of Americans are strugglingâ€¦ they borrowed during the pandemic when rates were low, and now theyâ€™re having to pay on that debt at a higher rate,â€ Zandi said. Though Fed chair Powell has acknowledged todayâ€™s K-shaped economy, a restrictive monetary policy is helping keep it in place, Sahm argued, making it unlikely for the two diverging K lines to come any closer together. â€œWe have a Fed thatâ€™s still trying to fight inflation thatâ€™s been elevated, and part of the tool that they have for fighting inflation is interest rates are elevated, and theyâ€™ve been elevated for some time,â€ Sahm said. â€œThis is the way restrictive monetary policy works: Itâ€™s going to hit households hardest who are more financially constrained.â€ Zandi had a different perspective. He argued that the gap will require policy changes far beyond the Fedâ€™s remit. â€œThe Fed canâ€™t fix the K-shaped economy,â€ he said. â€œIt can only stabilize prices and employment. The distributional effects are up to fiscal policy.â€ Instead, Zandi argued for a reversal of some choices made on the fiscal side that would â€œdo no harmâ€ to lower-and-middle-income Americans. â€œDonâ€™t impose tariffsâ€”that exacerbates inequality,â€ he said. â€œLower- and middle-income households spend a much higher share of their budget on imported products like food, clothing, and cars.â€ He also criticized President Donald Trumpâ€™s â€œhighly restrictiveâ€ immigration policy, which he said hurts jobs for industries that rely on immigrants, such as construction, agriculture and manufacturing broadly. Beyond just addressing self-inflicting wounds, Zandi argued that progress depends on both structural and cyclical forces: raising productivity through education, broad-based jobs creation, and ensuring that gains from AI will be equally shared. â€œIf the benefits of AI are distributed more broadly,â€ he said, â€œand if job losses are offset by new opportunities, weâ€™ll be fine.â€ Clear evidence of a two-tiered economy doesnâ€™t mean a recession is imminent, economists said. It does, however, mean that if economic indicators were to take a nosedive, the risk of a recession would increase. â€œThe K-shaped economy, the bifurcated economy, is potentially a more vulnerable economy,â€ Sahm said. Though layoff rates are still relatively low, if the rate of job cuts increased, there would be many more people in a job market where thereâ€™s not much hiring. The labor market today doesnâ€™t look like it did in the job-hopping era of 2023, even when interest rates were still high, Sahm noted. Right now, only the healthcare and hospitality sectors are adding jobs in earnest, creating a concentration of growth not optimal for economic stability. â€œAnytime you have that, youâ€™re more vulnerable if something bad happens,â€ Sahm said. Title: Fresh day fresh layoffs: TripAdvisor to cut 20% staff - here are the departments affected
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/fresh-day-fresh-layoffs-tripadvisor-to-cut-20-staff-here-are-the-departments-affected/articleshow/125162443.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-07T13:47:40Z
Full Content:
Tripadvisor is undergoing a major business overhaul. The travel review giant is merging divisions and cutting about 20% of its global workforce. This move aims to sharpen focus on travel experiences and integrate artificial intelligence across its platform. The company is also pursuing significant cost savings. This strategic shift prepares Tripadvisor for future growth in key travel market segments. Title: Main Street market moves: Here's what retail investors have done during a wild week for stocks
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/retail-investor-day-trader-trends-this-week-stock-market-volatility-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-07T13:05:50Z
Full Content:
Every time Joe publishes a story, youâ€™ll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking â€œSign upâ€, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insiderâ€™s Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Good morning and welcome to First Trade. It's no-Jobs Friday! Thanks to the government shutdown, we won't get new employment data. But don't worry, we have you covered with a roundup of private figures. Rundown But first, let's get in touch with the populace. Love Business Insider? Log into Google and make us a preferred source. Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up now Market musings Earnings season has been good. Perhapsâ€¦ too good. The run-ups in the stock market's favorite tech darlings after earnings last week apparently pushed valuations to a point where investors decided they'd had enough. It's led to a chaotic current week, with two separate valuation-driven sell-offs in a matter of three days. The institutional class is as split as ever over what the future holds. JPMorgan is recommending investors buy any dips. Billionaire Ray Dalio sees a short-term rally, and then a Fed-driven sell-off. And then there's the overhang of what will happen with President Trump's tariffs, which are facing a prolonged legal battle. But that only tells part of the story. As retail investing has exploded in popularity, so has the influence of the day-traders populating Reddit and Discord forums. Their behavior can often be a harbinger of what's to come, and the strategy team JPMorgan has conveniently been keeping tabs. Here are the four main themes that have dominated retail trading over the past week as volatility has raged. They went on their biggest buying spree in four months, almost entirely in mega-cap tech But they're not blindly buying market dips They're getting tired of gold and bitcoin after torrid rallies They're most excited about these meme stocks Judging by a "social interest score" tracked by JPMorgan, the "most hyped" stocks this past week were: Beyond Meat, Nokia, POET Technologies, UiPath, Palantir, Nvidia, Chipotle, and Reddit. Are you a retail investor that's leaning into these trends, or doing something completely different? Let us know what portfolio moves you've been making at firsttrade@businessinsider.com. On the heels of another difficult day in the market, console yourself with another example of the value-creating impact of AI deals. Snap stock surged as much as 18% after announcing a $400 million partnership with Perplexity AI, to incorporate its AI search engine into Snapchat. It's a good reminder that â€” even on the toughest of days â€” AI deals trump all, and can carry a stock to market-beating performance. Is the gig up for gold? At least as an S&P 500-crushing speculative asset? It appears so. Following a 20% run up through September and into October, the price of the precious metal has come back down to earth. The chart above, from JPMorgan, reflects a corresponding shift in sentiment, specifically among retail investors. Note the blue line, which shows that retail buying has plateaued. Each Friday, I'll discuss and review a piece of markets- or finance-related media: movies, books, TV shows, podcasts, etc. Today's entry is the movie "Boiler Room" (2000). There are some quotes at the beginning of "Boiler Room" â€” namely "I just want to get in" and "nobody wants to work for it anymore" â€” that echo the frivolous, fundamental-lite stock market activity that characterized the meme stock era. Right away, you know this is a movie that's going to deal with a popular evergreen theme: how to get rich quick. This film is best approached by suspending belief around the illegalities occurring. The schemes are sub-Wolf-of-Wall-Street penny-stock pump and dumps, where the companies don't even exist. It would never happen, at least this flagrantly, but that's not the point. It's all merely a vessel for the movie's top-notch cast of wisecracking early-2000s actors masquerading as stock-brokers. Vin Diesel executes a pitch-perfect sales call in front of 100 associates, closing the deal to rapt applause. Ben Affleck â€” the firm's head recruiter â€” delivers two scintillating motivational monologues to a room full of new hires. Key quote: "Anybody who tells you that money is the root of all evil, doesn't f**king have any." Leading man Giovanni Ribisi excels as a whip-smart, money-hungry youngster who's looking to make the leap from backroom poker games to stock-broking millionaire. And it feels like Jamie Kennedy is acting in a different movie â€” perhaps channeling his "Malibu's Most Wanted" character at some points â€” but it doesn't matter, he steals every scene he's in. At one point, the core group of brokers sit around trading extended recitations of the original "Wall Street." There's an analogy in there somewhere. Of course, the movie doesn't take place exclusively within the walls of the Long Island-based JT Marlin (yes, it's that obvious of a play on JPMorgan). The crew ventures into NYC a handful of times to beat up rival brokers from the "real" Wall Street, and party at a hotel in celebration of a new (fraudulent) IPO launch. These are electric and hilarious scenes, and they show that the movie is at its strongest when the core cast is ripping it up, even if a lot of the dialogue is offensive enough to be left in the year 2000. It's not the best finance movie of all time. But, for my money, it's the most fun. And for that reason it gets a 10/10 rating. Do you have any ideas about what I should review next? Tell me at firsttrade@businessinsider.com. Joe Ciolli, executive editor and anchor, in Chicago. Akin Oyedele, deputy editor, in New York. William Edwards, senior reporter, in New York. Steve Russolillo, chief news editor, in New York. Huileng Tan, senior reporter, in Singapore. Jump to

Title: You canâ€™t sit down! Peloton warns 900,000 customers to stop using bikes following reports of seat posts breaking and falling off
URL: https://road.cc/content/news/peloton-warns-900000-customers-stop-using-bikes-316737
Time Published: 2025-11-07T12:59:22Z
Full Content:
Like this site? Help us to make it better. Weâ€™re not sure if anyone working at Peloton is a fan of early 60s doo-wop group The Dovells. But if they are, the American bandâ€™s 1963 hit â€˜You Canâ€™t Sit Downâ€™ would form a rather apt soundtrack for the fitness brandâ€™s offices this week. On Thursday, Peloton issued a voluntary recall notice for almost 900,000 of its Original Series Bike+ models, following reports of a seat post defect which causes it to break and fall off, potentially resulting in, the company says, â€œinjury riskâ€ for users. Peloton has received three reports of the seat posts breaking and detaching during use, and two reports of injuries as a result of falls. Approximately 833,000 models have since been recalled in the US, while 44,800 bikes sold in Canada may also be affected, though Peloton says it is yet to receive any reports of seat posts breaking from its Canadian customers. The American company has warned users affected by the recall to stop using the Original Series Bike+ model immediately, while offering customers a free replacement seat post, which can be self-installed at home. > Peloton set to charge customers Â£70 for using second-hand bikes, as brandâ€™s sales finally rise by 0.2%, prompting shares to surge months after large-scale redundancies and restructuring The recall applies to Original Series Bike+ models manufactured in Taiwan between December 2019 and July 2022, which were sold in the United States and Canada from January 2020 to April 2025. The bikes were sold by Peloton directly, as well as through third-party retailers such as eBay, Amazon, and Dickâ€™s Sporting Goods, retailing at $2,495. Peloton says the affected models can be identified by the PL02 model number and a serial number beginning with the letter â€˜Tâ€™, on the label located inside the front fork, behind the front fork, or behind the flywheel. â€œThe integrity of our products and our membersâ€™ well-being are our top priorities,â€ Marcio Oliveira, Pelotonâ€™s senior vice president of Global Hardware Operations and Product Safety, said in a statement. â€œThe recall is due to the fact that the Original Series Bike+ seat post assembly can break during use, posing fall and injury hazards to the user. â€œPeloton has received three reports of seat posts breaking out of approximately 833,000 units sold in the US. Peloton has received no reports of a seat post breaking, out of 44,800 units sold in Canada. â€œWe are taking this opportunity to make replacement seat posts available to all affected Bike Plus users and we encourage them to contact us to receive the redesigned seat post as soon as possible.â€ > Peloton reports a defect in its bike seats after users report injuries, also announces ninth straight quarter of loss This latest recall comes over two years after Peloton issued an even larger recall notice concerning a faulty seat post, following the indentation of a defect in its Original Series PL-01 model, affecting 2.2 million of its entry-level bikes. That recall, issued in May 2023, came after 35 reports from users that the seat post was vulnerable to breaking at the weld joint, leading to 13 injuries, one customer sustaining a fractured wrist, cuts, and bruises. Last year, we reported that, after a turbulent period characterised by restructuring, a curtailed retailed presence, and a series of layoffs, Peloton saw its first sales increase in nine quarters, beating analystsâ€™ estimates and sending shares surging as much as 41 per cent. That rare bit of positive news came as the American fitness company controversially confirmed that it will start charging customers a Â£72 â€œactivation feeâ€ when they buy one of their exercise bikes second-hand. In May 2024, at the same time CEO Barry McCarthy stepped down, 15 per cent of Pelotonâ€™s workforce (around 400 people) was made redundant in another round of cuts. This latest cull, McCarthy claimed, was necessary to bring the New York-based brandâ€™s spending in line with its revenue, following three years of continuous losses thanks to sales of connected indoor fitness equipment plummeting as Covid-era restrictions eased. Title: They got laid off from the Microsoft country club and dumped into a hellish job market
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/microsoft-layoffs-workers-say-job-security-dead-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-07T10:04:01Z
Full Content:
Every time Jacob publishes a story, youâ€™ll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking â€œSign upâ€, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insiderâ€™s Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. After 31 years at Microsoft, Mike Kostersitz never saw it coming. In May, his team met with a senior leader about a new product. "Everybody was happy with the progress," said Kostersitz, then a principal product manager lead working on Microsoft's cloud computing platform Azure. "Everything was peachy." The following morning, he noticed a high-priority virtual meeting had been added to his calendar â€” and it wasn't good news. "Me and 120 other anonymous faces got told our jobs had been eliminated," said the Washington-based 60-year-old. His manager and two of his direct reports were also among the 6,000 employees affected. In July, roughly 9,000 more were laid off. Previously, in January and February, Microsoft had made nearly 2,000 performance-based cuts. I spoke with seven of the Microsoft workers who lost their jobs over the past 12 months. Microsoft was once known for its "country club" culture, but as Ashley Stewart reported for Business Insider earlier this year, leaders worried the company had gone soft, and it ramped up scrutiny on performance. A Microsoft spokesperson has said that most of this year's cuts were not performance-based but were intended to reduce management layers and streamline operations. Along with Amazon, Meta, and Google, Microsoft is one of many companies â€” from Silicon Valley to corporate America â€” that are fueling the Great Flattening. The tenure of the ex-Microsofters I spoke to ranged from a few years to more than three decades. Some said any sense of job security they once had was shattered. Several said they were caught off guard by their layoffs, citing factors like long tenure, no documented performance issues, and Microsoft's position as the world's third-most valuable company. They wondered: If job security is dead at Microsoft, will they find it anywhere else? Kostersitz is one of them. To help with his job search, he said a Microsoft-funded career advisor recommended he "de-age" his rÃ©sumÃ© by erasing work done in the 1980s and '90s. His LinkedIn profile now only shows professional experience since 2003. The advisor also emphasized that today's job market is an endurance test. "They said it's a game of chicken right now," he said. "The person who has the longer breath and can stick it out longer will get the job." Business Insider has heard from dozens of workers about how corporate strategy shifts, layoffs, and hiring slowdowns have affected their careers. If you have a story to share, contact this reporter via email at jzinkula@businessinsider.com, via Signal at jzinkula.29, or fill out this quick form. Use a personal email address, a nonwork WiFi network, and a nonwork device; here's our guide to sharing information securely. Read more on the topic: The experiences of laid-off Microsoft employees are part of a broader shift in corporate America. As Business Insider's Aki Ito has reported, job security was a defining feature of white-collar work during the postwar boom, a period when layoffs and firings were rare. However, globalization â€” and the overseas competition that accompanied it â€” gave rise to a new management philosophy focused on cost-cutting, downsizing, and viewing employees as interchangeable. It's not just about flattening. In cuts this year, companies have cited AI â€” if not directly for taking jobs, then for creating an environment in which companies can operate with leaner staff. It's what workers have been fearing will happen on a large scale as AI continues to improve and become increasingly omnipresent. While Microsoft's culture has evolved over the years, some laid-off employees said they believe the recent cuts show the company has entered a new era â€” one where avoiding layoffs appears to be a lower priority. The former Microsoft employees, in addition to dozens of other laid-off workers I've spoken with over the past year, told me they are grappling with how to protect their careers and financial well-being after an unexpected chop. Before Eduardo Noriega was laid off by Microsoft in May, he'd been nervous about his job security since 2009, when the company cut about 5,000 workers. "When I saw the layoff, I realized that job security isn't real," said Noriega, who's in his 50s and lives in Seattle. After weighing his options, Noriega concluded that his best chance at financial stability was to build a side business he could rely on if he ever lost his job. By the time he was cut in May, he'd spent nearly a decade building a staffing firm outside work hours â€” and was earning more from it than from his software engineering job. He said he had been hesitant to quit Microsoft and give up the steady paycheck, but the layoff gave him the push he needed to go all in. "I never dared to quit," he said. "And then Microsoft presented the layoff, and for me, that was like an exit." For other workers across corporate America, the challenge of landing a new role in today's economy has upped the stakes of sudden unemployment. While layoffs across the broader economy remain low by historical standards, white-collar roles have been particularly vulnerable. At the same time, US businesses are hiring at one of the slowest rates since 2013. "If you become unemployed, it's become much harder to find a job," said Laura Ulrich, director of economic research at the Indeed Hiring Lab. And because hiring was so much stronger in many industries just a few years ago, she said, the shift may feel especially stark. Ian Carter began working at Microsoft in 2021, and he said the company's layoffs in 2023 and 2024 sent a clear message: His job wasn't safe. "It felt like it didn't matter if you were a great worker or not," said the 33-year-old. "Everybody was at risk." Since being laid off in May from his position as a technical program manager, he has struggled to find a job. He drew on savings for several months to cover expenses and switched to a month-to-month lease on his Redmond, Washington, apartment â€” crossing his fingers that he'd land something soon. But he never did. In late October, he stored his belongings and moved to Florida to live with his family and save money while continuing his search. "Rent is expensive," he said, "but rent without income coming in is doubly expensive." In May, Joe Friend learned that he and 14 other members of his working group had been laid off. Friend's tenure at Microsoft spanned more than two decades across three stints, but this was the first time he hadn't left by choice. Friend said he believes there's been a culture shift within Microsoft â€” one that's left employees with less job security than they once had. Some of his concerns extend beyond Microsoft to Big Tech more broadly â€” which is why he plans to be highly selective about his next role. "I think I'd rather earn $50,000 a year doing something I'm excited about," said the 62-year-old. "It doesn't mean I won't jump back into a job, but it certainly won't be Big Tech." Deborah Hendersen took a different approach. After 14 years at Microsoft, Hendersen, a user researcher in the company's Xbox division, was one of about 9,000 employees laid off in July. "It wasn't so much like watching a car wreck," said the 45-year-old, who lives in Seattle. "It was more like you were in the car, knowing it was going to wreck." The moment she received a mysterious meeting invite that she suspected would bring bad news, she began laying the groundwork for her future. She shared a message internally and on LinkedIn to tell her network that she'd been laid off and to learn who else had been affected. This led to the creation of a Discord chat of more than a dozen affected colleagues, where people shared job opportunities, helped each other prepare for interviews, vented their frustrations, and celebrated their successes. Hendersen also turned to her network to find openings and secure referrals. One of the roles recommended to her was a user experience researcher position at Meta. She received a referral and, in late August, a job offer. Hendersen credited her network â€” and in particular her laid-off colleagues â€” for supporting her during this challenging period. "It's so helpful to have the support of other people who are going through it â€” both the highs and the lows," she said. "Because everybody gets turned down, gets their hopes up, and is just figuring out how to remain sane in a really challenging time." Jump to
--------------------------------------------------

Years of technological advancement, real-world deployment, and ecosystem building are now coming to a moment of fruition. Its shares, listed at HKD 27.1 per share, fell by over 13% when the market opened. WeRideâ€™s founder and CEO, Dr Tony Han, said on the day of the listing: â€œWe are deeply grateful to our partners, investors, customers, and every member of the WeRide team. Your trust and dedication have helped turn our vision of autonomous driving into reality. Over the past eight years, WeRide has evolved from technological innovation to commercial operation, becoming the only company worldwide with products holding autonomous driving permits in seven countries, and deployments in over 30 cities across 11 countries. We firmly believe that safe and reliable autonomous driving technology will deliver huge economic and social benefits. Our Hong Kong listing marks a new beginning, and we will continue to lead with technology, drive global commercial deployment, and deliver long-term, sustainable value for our shareholders and society.â€ Competition in the global robotaxi business is heating up, with Pony.ai and WeRide up against larger competitors such as Baiduâ€™s Apollo Go in China and Alphabetâ€™s Waymo in the US. Stellantis recently formed a new partnership with Uber, with Nvidia and Taiwanâ€™s Foxconn as their technology partners. Another Chinese automotive company, components maker Ningbo Joyson Electronic Corporation, also listed its shares on the HKEX on the same day, priced at HKD 22, before closing down by 8% at HKD 20.24. Donâ€™t let policy changes catch you off guard. Stay proactive with real-time data and expert analysis. Gain the recognition you deserve! The Just Auto Excellence Awards celebrate innovation, leadership, and impact. By entering, you showcase your achievements, elevate your industry profile, and position yourself among top leaders driving automotive industry advancements.
